dc:description: The UNC80 gene is located on chromosome 2 at 2q34 and encodes unc-80 homolog, NALCN channel complex subunit, which is a component of a sodium channel complex that regulates channel activity. UNC80 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive hypotonia, infantile, with psychomotor retardation and characteristic facies 2 in 2016 (Shamseldin et al., 26708753; Stray-Pedersen et al., 26708751). Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. This curation included 11 unique variants reported in eight cases from four publications (26708753: Shamseldin et al. 2016; 26708751: Stray-Pedersen et al. 2016; 30167850: Bramswig et al. 2018; 30771478: Kuptanon et al. 2019). One variant was a missense with experimental evidence of a loss-of-function effect; the remainder were predicted null variants. No segregation evidence was scored, but variants in this gene co-segregated with disease in three additional family members. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts) has been reached. Biallelic loss of function is implicated as the mechanism of disease. This gene-disease relationship is supported by knockout/knockdown models in C. elegans and Drosophila, including rescue in C.elegans with the model organism gene, as well as demonstration of an effect on trafficking of the UNC80 protein and sodium NALCN-dependent sodium leak current (18336069: Yeh et al. 2008; 24223770: Lear et al. 2013; 32620897: Wie et al. 2020). In summary, UNC80 is definitively associated with autosomal recessive hypotonia, infantile, with psychomotor retardation and characteristic facies 2. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date 4Nov2020 (SOP Version 7).

evidence.rdfs:label: Individual 23
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Neonatal hypotonia, failure to thrive, feeding difficulties, had mild respiratory distress on second day of life, severe intellectual disability, abnormal movements (limb choreic movements), speech impairment (nonverbal at 3 years), motor delay (cannot sit at 2 years, but can catch objects), low weight, and short length; facial features: triangular face, high and broad forehead, deep set eyes, large ears, fine hair, long face, strabismus, long thin fingers, pink nails, normal EEG and MRI (at 9 months), sleeping difficulties, sleep apnea, chronic constipation  (Supplemental table 2)

evidence.dc:description:
Default points since non-consanguineous; Compound heterozygous status confirmed - each parent had one of the variants; variants confirmed through Sanger sequencing; affected sibling also compound heterozygous for variants found in proband; cannot calculate LOD. 

Variants are located in exon 13 and 51 of 64, respectively and are therefore expected to undergo nonsense mediated decay. Both are absent from gnomAD.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 3; II.1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Normal birth weight, hypotonia noted at birth, persistent hypotonia, short stature (<<3rd percentile), normocephalic, esotropia, normal vision and hearing, eyelid ptosis, hypotonic facies, small hands and feet, severe global developmental delay and intellectual disability, no speech, babbles socially, expressive body language, sits with support, muscle weakness, seizures (starting at 6 months), severe constipation, feeding difficulties requiring G-tube at 15 years (supplemental use), hypersensitivity to stimuli, tactile aversion, brain MRI - no structural anomalies, EEG: encephalopathic background activity, mild scoliosis, normal thyroid gland function (additional details in Table 1 and supplemental document)

evidence.rdfs:label: Individual 27
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Neonatal hypotonia, failure to thrive, feeding difficulties, severe intellectual disability, abnormal movements, speech impairment (nonverbal), motor delay (cannot sit), cognitive impairment, low weight, short length, reduced head circumference; facial features: triangular face, high forehead, large ears, prominent antihelix, fine hair, long face, strabismus, thin upper lip, long thin fingers, proximally placed thumbs, EEG: mild focal right temporal discharges, brain MRI: mild fronto-parietal cortical atrophy, sleeping difficulties, increased tendency to infections, chronic constipation, hand flapping, excessive abnormal movement (Supplemental table 2; Fig 2d); metabolic workup was normal

evidence.dc:description:
Points reduced since consanguineous.
Variant is located in exon 54 of 64 and is therefore expected to undergo nonsense mediated decay. Absent from gnomAD

evidence.rdfs:label: Individual 18
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Neonatal hypotonia (at birth), jaundice that resolved within 72 hours after birth, severe global neurodevelopmental delay (10 mo), failure to thrive, severe intellectual disability, speech impairment (most probable), motor delay (although note that he is young), low weight, reduced head circumference; facial features: triangular face, high forehead, large ears, long face, strabismus, arched upper lip, normal brain MRI and EEG, left single palmar crease, delayed tooth eruption, long thin fingers (Supplemental table 2)

evidence.dc:description:
Points reduced since consanguineous.
Variant is located in exon 23 of 64 and is therefore expected to undergo nonsense mediated decay. 
Present in one allele in gnomAD.
Variant is absent from 650 Saudi Arabian individuals.

evidence.rdfs:label: F1_IV:5
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: severe truncal hypotonia since birth, progressive peripheral spasticity, profound global developmental delay, weakness, unable to sit or roll over, no speech, reduced weight (-5.2 SD), short stature (-3.7 SD), microcephaly (-3.2 SD), inattentive, no visual tracking, bilateral strabismus and nystagmus, brain MRI showed mild brain atrophy, skeletal survey showed diffuse osteopenia, high forehead, prominent nasal bridge, and tented upper lip, metabolic testing normal
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Chromosomal and microarray analysis - normal; HEXB and SMN1 testing - normal

evidence.dc:description:
Default points since non-consanguineous; Compound heterozygous status confirmed - each parent had one of the variants; sister had severe developmental delay and failure to thrive and passed away at 3 years of age (no additional information).  
Both variants are located in exon 19 of 64 and are therefore expected to undergo nonsense mediated decay.  One is absent and the second is present in one allele in gnomAD.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Initial visit due to developmental delay and failure to thrive; multiple facial features: downslanting palpebral fissures, triangular face, frontal bossing, low set ears, micrognathia, brachycephaly (additional phenotypes in table 3); constipation feeding difficulties, height and weight  <3rd percentile, myoclonic seizures, severe intellectual disability, hypotonia, global motor delay, happy disposition, sensory hypersensitivity, sleep disturbance, brain CT and MRI were unremarkable, moderate excretion of lactic acid in the urine.

evidence.dc:description:
Points reduced since consanguineous; Variant and wild-type Unc80 (constructs from mouse cDNA) were transfected into HEK293T cells. Electrophysiological experiments (patch clamp) showed that NALCN currents were significantly reduced in cells transfected with variant Unc80 when compared to wildtype Unc80 (Figure 4). Variant confirmed through Sanger sequencing.
Variant is present in gnomAD; Ashkenazi Jewish (4/8516) AF=0.0004697; Homozygotes=0

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1; IV.1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Neonatal-onset persistent hypotonia, feeding difficulties requiring G-tube at 2 years, short stature, reduced head circumference (43 cm (<<3rd percentile, or 4 SD), hypotonic facies, small hands and feet, severe global developmental delay and intellectual disability, no speech, poor eye contact and minimal interest in surroundings, can sit for a few seconds (4 years), non-ambulatory, muscle weakness, seizures (starting at 3 months, but none since 3 years old) [generalized tonic-clonic], severe constipation, sleep disturbance, sleep apnea, thin corpus callosum detected through MRI, abnormal EEG, nonspecific myopathic changes on muscle biopsy, choreiform movements, hypothyroidism, generalized joint laxity (additional details in Table 1 and supplemental document).

evidence.rdfs:label: Individual 20
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Global neurodevelopmental delay, neonatal hypotonia and failure to thrive (all at 4 months old), microcephaly, brachycephaly, muscle wasting, feeding difficulties, severe intellectual disability, abnormal movements (limb choreic movements); autistic behavior, speech impairment (although note that she is still young), motor delay (although note that she is still young), low weight, reduced head circumference, short length; facial features: triangular face, high and broad forehead, deep set eyes, large ears, long face, strabismus, upturned nose (possibly familial), normal EEG, sleeping difficulties, increased tendency to infections, chronic constipation  (Supplemental table 2)

evidence.dc:description: Reduced points since recapitulation of phenotype; however, overlap is limited considering phenotypes observed in humans

Through backcrossing for 6-8 generations in Drosophila melanogaster, homozygous mutant strains were produced (two strains: P-element insertion GS12792 into exon 18 [Unc80GS12792] and imprecise excision GS12792 retaining 14 bp which results in a shift in the reading frame [Unc80x42]) introducing a stop codon. Both showed defects in locomotor activity levels (anticipatory behavior and free-running rhythmicity - P<0.05) when compared to wild-type controls. (Figure 1 and Table 1)
evidence.rdfs:label: Drosophila model

evidence.dc:description: Points not awarded for complete KO is lethal within 24 hours and only phenotype observed is sleep apnea.

Knock out mice generated using the CRISPR/Cas9 technique (UNC80 truncated at amino acid position 47) did not survive beyond 24 hours and showed sleep apnea. No other phenotypes were noted (Figure 1). Heterozygous mice were viable with no abnormalities.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse model

evidence.dc:description: Reduced points since recapitulation of phenotype; however, overlap is limited considering phenotypes observed in humans

In C. elegans, three unc-80 alleles (hp369 (stop gained; Arg649Ter), e1272 (stop gained; Trp2463Ter), and e1069 (splice site variant resulting in premature stop codon after Leu2428)) (Figure S4A shows details on these variants) all individually showed recessive fainter phenotypes (locomotion defects including paralysis and crawling defects) (video S6); RNAi knockdown of an open reading frame F25C8.3, which corresponds to unc-80, also showed the fainter phenotype.
evidence.rdfs:label: C. elegans model

evidence.dc:description: Reduced points. While the full phenotype is rescued, there is limited phenotype overlap with what is observed in humans

In C. elegans, co-injection of genomic fragments only containing F25C8.3 resulted in rescue of the fainter phenotype in unc-80 mutant e1272 (Videos S9). In addition, expression of unc-80 driven by a pan-neuronal promoter also rescued the fainter phenotype in unc-80 mutant e1272 (Video S12).
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue in c. elegans

evidence.dc:description: Default points awarded

When WT RFP-tagged UNC80 was transfected in cultured hippocampal neurons from mice, imaging showed presence in the soma, axons, and dendrites. However, five RFP-tagged UNC80 constructs truncated at various positions, where the C-terminus was removed, only localized to the soma and not the dendrites or axons. Additional experiments to identify the specific region, showed that the distal C-terminal ~300 amino acids (but before position 3000) is likely to be involved in trafficking of UNC80 (Figure 7 and supplementary figure 2)
evidence.rdfs:label: Localization defect in mouse hippocampal neurons

evidence.dc:description: Default points awarded

Using patch clamp testing, NALCN-dependent sodium leak current was compared between hippocampal neurons cultured from wild-type and UNC80 KO mice. UNC80 KO neurons showed decreased current. NALCN protein levels were comparable to wild-type, but the NALCN current was significantly reduced (Figure 2f). Transfection of UNC80 cDNA into the KO neurons fully restored the NALCN-dependent sodium leak current.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patch clamp testing

evidence.dc:description: Default points awarded. Similar expression information, i.e. mainly in the brain, was also noted in the GTEx data in the Human Protein Atlas

RNA was extracted from the following tissues: brain, liver, spleen, kidney, lung, heart from P60 adult mice. Expression of the murine ortholog Unc80 was evaluated using RT-PCR in the six tissue types. Expression was only noted in the mouse brain and not the other tissues (Figure S1).
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression in mouse brain
